comment.body: This is what's expected. Because of the extra long header, the http request can't be read fully. If we instead send a request with a large body, it will actually succeed because it gets redirected and handled.

pull_request.title: update quic-go to v0.39.3
pull_request.body: The patch releases contain an ECN fix on certain Linux platforms, and a fix for a bug that allowed negotiating TLS 1.2 (or older) over QUIC. As far as I can tell it doesn't have any security implications (the TLS handshake fails at a later stage), but it's just super weird.

comment.body:
The error produced by the listener-wrapper isn't what's expected.
Expected:
```
{"level":"debug","ts":1698406739.916438,"logger":"http.stdlib","msg":"http: TLS handshake error from 127.0.0.1:60526: redirected HTTP request on HTTPS port"}
```

Received:
```
{"level":"debug","ts":1698406739.916438,"logger":"http.stdlib","msg":"http: TLS handshake error from 127.0.0.1:60526: couldn't read HTTP request"}
```

Granted, those lines aren't returned to the error var here, they're printed by the logger.

comment.body: This _seems_ (reality will tell if truly) easy to test. Do you think you can add one? I can try writing up a test case.
Since we removed the closure, I think we could invert the condition to `if c.once { return c.r.Read(p) }`, i.e. early return, reduces indentation one level.

comment.body: Okay :man_shrugging: it's been too long since I first implemented this so I don't remember if I added `c.Conn.Close()` after testing something and noticing it's better to have, or if I just added it cause it felt like the right thing to do. I dunno. If it looks okay with `curl` and in the browser, then it should be fine I guess.
